newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil makes modest gains.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil makes modest gains.

text.p: Singapore gas oil swaps rose slightly at midday on Monday despite a large hike to crude prices on Friday as lacklustre regional demand kept a lid on any big gains, traders said.
"The market rose this morning because of crude but sentiment remains bearish. Regional demand is still not that strong," a trader said.
June swaps were last quoted at $25.60/$25.70 per barrel, up 30 cents from Thursday, while July was indicated at $25.25/$25.33, also up 30 cents.
June swaps traded earlier in the day three times at $25.65, brokers said.
The swaps market was pushed up slightly after crude recorded another big increase on Friday with July Brent rising 86 cents to close at $20.35 per barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange.
Traders said the market remains well supported at current levels and the firmer crude prices will give some traders a good base to raise their physical bids.
On Friday, three 150,000 barrel cargoes traded, two at $25.20 and one at $25.70 per barrel, all on a free-on-board Singapore basis.

The $25.70 deal was the first time in about three weeks that physical gas oil traded above the $25.50 mark and is seen as an indication that the buyers may look to give the market a new push, traders said.
The May/June spread traded at about 10 cents this morning despite talks that there are some unsold prompt cargoes in Singapore.
Traders said the May/June trade reflected market confidence that the prompt cargoes should be able to find a home without much difficulty.
Fuel oil was steady despite the crude surge with June quoted unchanged at $101/$102 per tonne.
